scenario:
The Dow Jones Industrial Average had a 12.9% return in 2024, lower than the S&P 500's 23.3% and the Nasdaq Composite's 28.6%. Eight of the 30 Dow components lost value, including Boeing and Nike, which are both dividend-paying value stocks. 

Boeing, the worst-performing Dow stock in 2024, has a new CEO and low expectations, making it a potential turnaround candidate. However, it has cut its dividend and has no passive-income potential at this time. Nike, with a 2.1% dividend yield, is also a turnaround candidate, but its multi-decade moat in shoes and athletic apparel is under threat from competitors.

The healthcare sector, which makes up 10% of the S&P 500, was heavily sold off in the final three months of 2024, making Dow healthcare stocks some of the poorest-performing components. However, Amgen, Merck, Johnson & Johnson, and UnitedHealth could beat the S&P 500 if investors gravitate toward value and away from growth stocks in 2025. These stocks have fallen to attractive levels based on forward earnings guidance and have dividend yields ranging from 1.6% to 3.5%.

McDonald's and Chevron are two industry-leading businesses with long track records of increasing the dividends they return to shareholders. McDonald's has 48 consecutive years of dividend increases and a 2.5% yield, while Chevron has 37 consecutive years of dividend increases and a 4.1% yield.
